summary: This is an email chain from July 2020 regarding an invitation to a virtual panel discussion about the Netflix series 'Filthy Rich' which covers Jeffrey Epstein. The discussion is hosted by ECPAT-USA and features experts discussing how Epstein used his wealth and power to carry out abuse. The email expresses concern about whether a mentioned 'survivor' is an Epstein survivor.

persons.name: Lori L. Cohen
persons.context: Sends the initial invitation for the panel discussion and is listed as the moderator of the event. Her pronouns (she/her/hers) are included in her email signature.

persons.name: Lisa Bryant
persons.context: Featured as a panelist in the discussion about the series 'Filthy Rich' covering Jeffrey Epstein.

persons.name: Kathryn Stamoulis
persons.context: Featured as a panelist in the discussion about the series 'Filthy Rich' covering Jeffrey Epstein.

persons.name: Fernando Camacho
persons.context: Featured as a panelist in the discussion about the series 'Filthy Rich' covering Jeffrey Epstein.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The subject of the panel discussion and the Netflix series 'Filthy Rich'. The document states the discussion will cover how he used his wealth and power to carry out abuses.

connections.description: Cohen is the Executive Director and Camacho is a Board Member of the same organization, ECPAT-USA.
Both are featured as panelists on the same ECPAT-USA discussion panel.
Cohen's organization is hosting a panel discussion analyzing Epstein's crimes and methods, indicating a professional/advocacy focus on his case.

events.title: ECPAT-USA Panel on 'Filthy Rich'
events.description: A virtual panel discussion via Zoom about the Netflix series 'Filthy Rich', focusing on how Jeffrey Epstein used his wealth and power to carry out his abuses. Features director Lisa Bryant, psychologist Kathryn Stamoulis, and board member Hon. Fernando Camacho, moderated by Lori L. Cohen.

keyFacts: The email chain shows ongoing public and advocacy group discussion of the Epstein case in July 2020, following the release of the Netflix series 'Filthy Rich'.
ECPAT-USA, a child protection organization, hosted a panel to analyze how Epstein used his wealth and power to facilitate abuse.

An email expresses uncertainty about whether a 'survivor' mentioned in relation to the panel is a general survivor or specifically an Epstein survivor, indicating sensitivity around victim identification.
The document reflects the continued relevance of the Epstein case to anti-trafficking and child protection work years after his arrest and death.
